title: One thing the majority of this sub disagrees with.
body: Toxicity does not make you win\lose more games, if you have a toxic teammate, you aren't losing because of him 90% of the times, you just don't belong in higher elo.

replies.body: A toxic teammate could make the person they are harassing start running it down, stop trying, or just afk, securing a loss in a winnable game. You literally will get nothing out of telling someone how bad they are.

> [{quoted}](name=Kelg,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=roeEy4Au,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2018-07-30T10:50:58.025+0000)
>
> A toxic teammate could make the person they are harassing start running it down, stop trying, or just afk, securing a loss in a winnable game. You literally will get nothing out of telling someone how bad they are.

No, inters choose to int; they are not made to do that.  Please do not reinforce the idea that ends in "It's not my fault I sold my items for Mobis and a Righteous Glory." just because you disagree with him.

I don't think that's the point Kelg is making.
The feeder is obviously still to blame in such cases, but it doesn't change the fact that **some** cases of feeding could be avoided if people didn't throw around unnecessary insults. Those cases will then clearly result in a lower chance to win if you have somebody in your team that is prone to harass others.

Let's say you're in a bar, you and a friend are in a tense argument with some strangers. Your friend then figures it's a good idea to insult said strangers' mothers. The strangers respond by punching you and your friend in the face.
Those people are clearly responsible for their own actions and can be charged with assault. But don't tell me you wouldn't be upset about the way your friend pointlessly escalated the situation, even if you might not directly blame him for your broken nose.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=roeEy4Au,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2018-07-30T16:50:20.885+0000)
>
> I don't think that's the point Kelg is making.
> The feeder is obviously still to blame in such cases, but it doesn't change the fact that **some** cases of feeding could be avoided if people didn't throw around unnecessary insults. Those cases will then clearly result in a lower chance to win if you have somebody in your team that is prone to harass others.

Correct, that's not the end point he was going for, but his reasons reinforce that idea.

>Let's say you're in a bar, you and a friend are in a tense argument with some strangers. Your friend then figures it's a good idea to insult said strangers' mothers. The strangers respond by punching you and your friend in the face.
>Those people are clearly responsible for their own actions and can be charged with assault. But don't tell me you wouldn't be upset about the way your friend pointlessly escalated the situation, even if you might not directly blame him for your broken nose.

Yeah, they are but the reasoning of **_what_** he wrote disputes that.  That argument can "make the person" do that, "make" as in the cause, the cause being what has that responsibility for the result.

That's just the thing though: Logically speaking it **is** the cause. There is a clear causal link in this scenario between the harassment and the intentional feeding.

It's important to keep in mind though, that cause and responsibility are not the same thing. Unfortunately I'm way too tired to get into a philosophical discussion over partial responsibility for another person's actionsâ€¦ fortunately, it's not really the subject of this thread though.

Statistically speaking, toxicity **causes** a lower chance to win. That's what the example is supposed to illustrate (again, provided I'm interpreting it correctly), and that's what the OP is denying to be the case.
Reading anything more into that post simply seems excessive to me.

>if you have a toxic teammate, you aren't losing because of him 90% of the times...

Correct, but toxicity DOES decrease your team's chance of victory. Just not by a number anywhere NEAR this high.

>One thing the majority of this sub disagrees with.

Um, nope. Someone spending their time raging very definitely affects whether or not we win the game. Like it or not, morale, communication and teamwork play a significant role.

you don't even play ranked, probably because you have ranked anxiety, what makes you even think you know how this game works if you dont even play the competitive part of it? 

which is why the majority of the people who blame toxic players for losing game are below plat, SURPRISE SURPRISE
The surefire way to lose an argument is to show you've given up by resorting to personal attacks instead of actual discussion.

***COUGH*** 3,000+ ARAM GAMES ***COUGH***

Maybe you should consider that there are competitive ways to play other than ranked? The day they do ranked Ascension, count me in.

> [{quoted}](name=Silent Gravity,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=LaBWZQyl,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2018-04-14T22:09:02.348+0000)
>
> 
> Situation 1: Everyone on the team plays to the best of their ability. When someone is caught out, the others do what they can to salvage the situation: using cc and damage to zone the enemies away, pressuring elsewhere on the map, or even just clearing the wave to buy time until the caught member can respawn to minimize losses.
> 
> Situation 2: Whenever someone overextends, or gets ganked, or asks for help stopping the other team's baron rush, or whatever, the team does nothing to assist because it's "what that jerk deserves".
> 
> Which situation has a greater chance of winning? Which situation is more likely once people are whining at each other?

Many times, I have seen toxic players intentionally lose the game. They punish the team because they weren't babysat and turned into a hypercarry when they didn't have the skill to even be one despite their champ pick.

I have played games where I'm carrying lanes that probably got boosted and are losing their lane horribly, but they're still trying their best and contributing to fights and following the team and even though their contribution isn't the best, their contribution is significantly higher than other toxic players who intentionally throw because they're throwing a tantrum because they lost in lane and it's the team's fault and not their fault.
others toxicity doesnt make a person win or lose more games, but BEING toxic does since it makes it more likely for your team to tilt or not play with you correctly.

Also, consider this:  People don't *like* playing with toxice players.  Something I'd be interested in seeing would be a comparison of surrender rates in games w/ toxic behavior present vs. surrender rates in games w/o toxic behavior.  And yes, I would also include surrender attempts

My guess?  more surrenders/surrender attempts happen in toxic games.
This seems like an opinion and not a fact. If you have real statistics please share. Even games with correlation not following toxic=lower chance of win
Also: This is not a sub, because this is not reddit.
I disagree with what you think we disagree on.
